metadata.synopsis: Gale is a Companion.This dialogue can trigger as COM (if the players approach Elminster with Gale as a companion), as a regular dialogue (if the players approach Elminster while Companion Gale is in the camp) or a CFM (if the player skips Elminster altogether).It can trigger in either Creche or SCL.
metadata.how_to_trigger: - Give Gale at least one magic item, go to SCL_Main_A, and approach Elminster at S_ORI_Gale_ElminsterPoint_SCL_975ef355-b68e-4061-bda8-b774e8ff552fContinue through the dialogue until you are sent to camp.OR- Give Gale at least one magic item, go to CRE_Main_A, and approach Elminster at S_ORI_Gale_ElminsterPoint_CRE_f5a225ef-d123-449f-98e2-53309a21979bContinue through the dialogue until you are sent to camp.OR- Go to SCL_Main_A- Queue night NIGHT_ORI_Gale_ElminsterVisit

28.speaker: Weary Traveller
28.text: Ah! There you are. I hope you don't mind my having ingratiated myself into the most palatable graces of your provisions. You find me quite sated indeed.

0.speaker: Weary Traveller
0.text: Mmm, yes, what a delightful wedge of Old Elturian that was. Doesn't do to parley on an empty stomach, you know. Makes one's words frivolous when they should be grave.

63.speaker: Weary Traveller
63.text: My thanks for your excellent guidance. Ah! And yonder I spy the object of my pursuit.

104.speaker: Weary Traveller
104.text: Ah, finally they stir. True adventurers get up with the lark, I always say, but if there are larks to be found in these lands, they must fancy themselves akin to nightingales.
104.context: CinematicNodeContext: Elminster is at camp when the players and Gale wake up.

62.speaker: Weary Traveller
62.text: Your friend here denied having the pleasure of your acquaintance, Gale, but I'll assume this feigned ignorance was committed with more or less noble intentions.

43.speaker: Weary Traveller
43.text: Come, come, up you both stand. I, for one, am dying to find out what's for breakfast.

47.speaker: Gale
47.text: Must have been his simulacrum you bested. He always was a cautious traveller.
47.context: InternalNodeContext: Aside, to the AvatarNodeContext: Referring to player previously 'killing' Elminster - it was an illusion. Low and an aside to the player, not meant for anyone else's ears

21.speaker: Weary Traveller
21.text: The very same, Gale. And a fair bit miffed he is, too, finding himself forced to expose his best pair of boots to so many miles of country road on your behalf.

90.speaker: Gale
90.text: I don't understand. How so on my behalf?

73.speaker: Weary Traveller
73.text: I was bid to spare neither time nor my own self to find you. She sent me, Gale. You know of whom I speak.

31.speaker: Gale
31.text: But why? Out with it, Elminster. Please!

106.speaker: Weary Traveller
106.text: Young man, has your sojourn away from Waterdeep washed away your decorum as well as your patience?

102.speaker: Weary Traveller
102.text: Nigh a tenday I've gone without honest fare worthy of the name - drank naught but what the sky entitled my thirst.

1.speaker: Weary Traveller
1.text: Why, some bread, cheese, and a cup of wine would appear unto me a feast! Surely you won't begrudge me a mite of rest and repast before I get 'out with it'?

77.speaker: Player
77.text: Yes, Gale. Where is your decorum?

38.speaker: Player
38.text: Surely you could have conjured any feast you liked.

26.speaker: Weary Traveller
26.text: Alas, such luxuries require the beneficence of time, and time, as I'm sure our friend here will attest, is the very luxury of which we're all too bereft.

67.speaker: Weary Traveller
67.text: Fine, fine, I'll turn a deaf ear to the clarion calls with which my scorned stomach beseeches me. Graver matters are at hand.

76.speaker: Weary Traveller
76.text: Plenty to digest, after all. A good deal to stew over, if you will. Words ladled with import should be savoured so as to better absorb their meaning, wouldn't you agree?

87.speaker: Weary Traveller
87.text: I, er... ahem. That is to say...

10.speaker: Weary Traveller
10.text: Gale, m'boy, I've come to address a most pressing matter. I'll speak as plainly as I can, forswearing the accustomed frills that decorate my speech.

91.speaker: Weary Traveller
91.text: I'm here on behalf of Mystra. The message and the charge I bring you are hers.

93.speaker: Player
93.text: It must be a great honour to be so entrusted by your god.

97.speaker: Gale
97.text: I could debate you on that.

48.speaker: Weary Traveller
48.text: You know where you went wrong, Gale, and I trust you've told your fellow traveller here the nature of your ills.

16.speaker: Gale
16.text: I can't say that so far I've volunteered the entire truth.

84.speaker: Weary Traveller
84.text: Do you mean to say you never bothered to disclose how dangerous you are?

81.speaker: Gale
81.text: Not in so many words, no.

50.speaker: Weary Traveller
50.text: Then you two have much to discuss after I'll have taken my leave.

29.speaker: Weary Traveller
29.text: In short, Gale - through his own doing - has become a living explosive that could wipe from this world this very gathering, and much more besides.

40.speaker: Weary Traveller
40.text: For his folly, Mystra forsook him, but now she has decreed he is to be given a chance of redemption.

45.speaker: Weary Traveller
45.text: She would consider what she considers to be forgiveness.

24.speaker: Weary Traveller
24.text: Mystra is aware of the misadventures that have befallen you both. She knows of your strife with the Absolute, that most insidious of evils.

74.speaker: Player
74.text: If the goddess herself is aware, I wouldn't say no to some divine intervention.

8.speaker: Weary Traveller
8.text: The very purpose of my presence - in a roundabout sort of way.

27.speaker: Weary Traveller
27.text: You must know that the Absolute is more dangerous than you can possibly conceive. It threatens all who live - even those who are undying. It threatens the gods, the Weave, the very fabric of the universe itself.

65.speaker: Weary Traveller
65.text: That is why I have come here to charge you, Gale, with its destruction. It is Mystra's belief that only you can.

60.speaker: Player
60.text: Mystra is mistaken. I will be the Absolute's destroyer.

49.speaker: Player
49.text: She'd do well to place her trust in me in equal measure.

55.speaker: Weary Traveller
55.text: I doubt not your conviction. But Gale has an unnatural advantage.

78.speaker: Player
78.text: Hogwash. Idle beliefs and false hopes.

18.speaker: Weary Traveller
18.text: That which I speak of, as Gale well knows, is neither idle nor false. Rather it is... unnatural.

86.speaker: Weary Traveller
86.text: That which renders him so dangerous is an orb of Netherese origin that is buried within his chest. And that, Gale, is how we arrive at the heart of my directive.

100.speaker: Weary Traveller
100.text: Mystra has granted me the power to stop the clock, as it were, on the orb's rush to overpower you. Instead, you will be able to unleash its lethal combustion at will.

88.speaker: GROUP_Daisy
88.text: Interesting. This could be help or hindrance - we shall have to see.

23.speaker: Weary Traveller
23.text: You must find the Heart of the Absolute, whatever that may be, and use yourself as the catalyst that will burn it from this world.

25.speaker: Player
25.text: That's monstrous! You're tasking him to kill himself.

70.speaker: Gale
70.text: He is not. But it seems that Mystra is.

44.speaker: Player
44.text: I'm surprised that Mystra demands such a sacrifice. This is hardly her way.

101.speaker: Gale
101.text: I'm glad it's not just me.

20.speaker: Player
20.text: Say what you will, but you can't force Gale to go through with this.

71.speaker: Gale
71.text: No indeed. But I think she trusts me to.

42.speaker: Player
42.text: We'll be rid of both the Absolute and Gale in one fell swoop. Win-win.

3.speaker: Weary Traveller
3.text: I may be slow to anger, but I will not have you sully this moment of most sorrowful import with ill-considered levity!

37.speaker: Gale
37.text: It's all right, Elminster. If ever gallows humour were appropriate, this is its grim-smiling hour.

15.speaker: Weary Traveller
15.text: It brings me no pleasure saying this, my friend, but such is Mystra's will. Yours must be the sacrifice that will undo the Absolute. And for your sacrifice, you will be redeemed - such is Mystra's promise.

59.speaker: Weary Traveller
59.text: With that, I've said my sorry piece, and need only bestow unto thee the charm I was bid.

75.speaker: Weary Traveller
75.context: CinematicNodeContext: Elinster speaks this spell and as he does so and makes hand gestures, a magical effect emanates from him and envelops Gale.

52.speaker: Weary Traveller
52.text: It is done. Both charge and charm have been committed into your care.

33.speaker: Weary Traveller
33.text: To you, I commit into care Gale himself. I count on you to shepherd him well on this strangest of journeys.
33.context: CinematicNodeContext: He addresses the player now, rather than Gale.

80.speaker: Player
80.text: On my honour, it shall be done.

51.speaker: Gale
51.text: On my honour, I'm not sure yet I can say the same.

14.speaker: Player
14.text: There's still a long journey ahead. We'll find another way.

41.speaker: Weary Traveller
41.text: Like moons make swell and wane the nescient seas, so too the sky-strewn gods ordain the tidal fates of mortal days.

2.speaker: Weary Traveller
2.text: And yet - a notion born in lonely hours - come ebb, come flow, come all that is beyond the breadth of our dominion: be a moon unto yourself.

32.speaker: Weary Traveller
32.text: Even the waves of fate can break upon the shores of will.

96.speaker: Gale
96.text: Farewell, Elminster. I'm glad she chose you.

95.speaker: Player
95.text: I am not his keeper, and I do not accept your charge.

92.speaker: Gale
92.text: Nor would I expect you to. It is too bleak a task to demand of anyone.

66.speaker: Player
66.text: It sounds like the most insidious of evils was actually Gale all along.

83.speaker: Gale
83.text: By circumstance, but not by purpose, I swear. I never intended you any harm.

19.speaker: Weary Traveller
19.text: His acts were misguided, yes, but I assure you that deep down he has a heart of - let's say at least silver. Which is more than can be said for the foe you face.

7.speaker: Player
7.text: If even the gods know, why are we facing these threats alone?

98.speaker: Weary Traveller
98.text: They choose the instruments of their will with great precision. Sometimes the single drops we think we are do not realise what waves we are building up to be.

17.speaker: Weary Traveller
17.text: Do not discount yourself, and by the same token, do not discount your enemy.

107.speaker: Player
107.text: You wouldn't happen to know of a cure, would you? Some all-powerful, parasite-withering spell, perhaps?

46.speaker: Weary Traveller
46.text: Alas. The creature that afflicts you, the ill-begotten magic that it weaves, is inextricably conjoined with both the greater purpose and the greater master that it serves.

89.speaker: Weary Traveller
89.text: You know where you went wrong, Gale. We needn't dwell on that here and now. But even so, you're to be given a chance of redemption.

22.speaker: Player
22.text: You were sent here as an actual divine messenger?

109.speaker: Gale
109.text: Mystra's delicate feet are ill-suited for the hardships of the road.

99.speaker: Player
99.text: I'm surprised she sent you in the first place after Gale's... debacle.

36.speaker: Gale
36.text: Thank you for that most considerate reminder.

64.speaker: Player
64.text: What message and what charge would that be?

4.speaker: Gale
4.text: The long-awaited question. Now - if you please, Elminster - for the too-long-awaited answer.

58.speaker: Player
58.text: Speak fast, then, for none of this pertains to me.

35.speaker: Player
35.text: I suppose we could part with a few of our rations.

85.speaker: Weary Traveller
85.text: And a great kindness that would be! See, Gale? Even in these barren parts, the art of hospitality begets inspired new works if one only keeps up the practice.

54.speaker: Player
54.text: I'm not in the habit of taking in vagabonds.

57.speaker: Weary Traveller
57.text: Oh? And what is he, then, wandering these forlorn barrens over seven hundred miles from home?
57.context: CinematicNodeContext: On ‘he’, he points to Gale.NodeContext: On ‘he’, he points to Gale.
